Yes, certainly. Here are a few examples of how WHO's initiatives have improved public health in developing countries:

1. Global Polio Eradication Initiative: WHO has played a significant role in the global effort to eradicate polio. Since the initiative's launch in 1988, the number of polio cases worldwide has decreased by 99%, from over 350,000 to just a few hundred cases in a few countries. This initiative has been particularly successful in developing countries, where the disease has historically been most prevalent.

2. Millennium Development Goals: WHO played a leading role in the development and implementation of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), which included a range of health-related targets such as improving maternal and child health, reducing the burden of infectious diseases, and combating malnutrition. Through WHO's efforts and the work of partners around the world, the MDGs helped to drive significant progress in improving public health in developing countries.

3. Scaling Up Treatment for HIV/AIDS: WHO played a critical role in advocating for and facilitating the scaling up of HIV/AIDS treatment in many developing countries. This initiative has helped to improve access to antiretroviral therapy for millions of people living with HIV/AIDS, leading to significant reductions in illness and mortality from the disease.

4. Roll Back Malaria: WHO has been a key partner in the Roll Back Malaria (RBM) initiative, which aims to reduce the burden of malaria in developing countries. Through RBM, WHO has supported countries in the development and implementation of national malaria control strategies, as well as in the procurement and distribution of essential malaria prevention and treatment tools.

Overall, these examples highlight how WHO's initiatives have contributed to improving public health in developing countries, helping to reduce the burden of disease and improve access to essential health services.
